# Government Tender Announcement

## Title
Experimental and Numerical Investigation of Three-Dimensional Turbulent Flows for Downstream Migrating Fish

## Solicitation Number
30003283

## Publication Date
November 18, 2022

## Tender Closing Date
November 29, 2022, at 23:00:00 (Eastern Standard Time)

## Contracting Entity
Fisheries and Oceans Canada

## Work Description
The objective of this research contract is to investigate the role of hydrodynamics, including turbulence, on bypass designs for downstream migrating fish. The research aims to improve conditions for safer passage of fish through bypasses, minimizing injury or mortality risks.

The work will involve:

1. Literature review of current knowledge on fish passage efficiency and effectiveness.
2. Design and fabrication of modified spillway and bar rack models for experimental studies.
3. Experimental investigations using three-component velocity measurements with a stereoscopic particle image velocimetry system.
4. Comprehensive analysis of velocity data to understand turbulence characteristics and eddies.
5. Assessment of changes in hydraulic conditions on the swimming behavior and movement of downstream migrating fish.
6. Creation of a repository of benchmark databases for validating computational fluid dynamics (CFD) models.
7. Literature review on the predictive performance of CFD models.
8. CFD analysis of turbulent flow over spillway models.

This contract is a competitive tender, open to all qualified bidders. The contract will be awarded based on the evaluation of the technical merits of the proposals.

* Canada-UK Trade Continuity Agreement (Canada-UK TCA)
* Canada-Ukraine Free Trade Agreement (CUFTA)
* Canadian Free Trade Agreement (CFTA)
* Canada-Honduras Free Trade Agreement
* Canada-Chile Free Trade Agreement (CCFTA)

## Region of Opportunity
This tender is applicable to the region of Canada. The work will be performed in Manitoba.

## Tender Documents
The tender documents are available on the Government of Canada's procurement website. Bidders must register and log in to access the documents.
